summary: **Decision:** Built Cosmic Atlas - comprehensive space data aggregation platform with 50+ APIs, intelligent caching, and real-time WebSocket streaming in monorepo architecture. **Problem:** User requested advanced space data platform pulling all public APIs (satellites, telescopes, Mars rovers, ISS, space weather, exoplanets, launches) with interactive live data and deep exploration capabilities. Existing solutions fragmented across multiple sites with no unified access. **Alternatives:** Simple API wrapper (rejected: no value-add, no caching, no real-time), single-domain focus like just satellites (rejected: user wanted comprehensive coverage), client-side only without backend (rejected: exposes API keys, no caching, rate limit issues), REST-only without WebSocket (rejected: user wanted real-time updates). **Trade-offs:** Comprehensive scope increases complexity (58 files, 18K lines); accepted for unique value proposition. Monorepo structure adds overhead but ensures type sharing and unified architecture. 9 API clients to maintain vs simplicity; accepted for complete coverage. **Impact/Scope:** Establishes reusable pattern for multi-API aggregation platforms. Demonstrates: (1) Base APIClient class with intelligent caching by data volatility (5s for ISS to 24hr for static data), (2) Rate limit management with automatic retry and fallback APIs, (3) WebSocket real-time streaming architecture, (4) Monorepo structure with shared types package, (5) Production error handling with graceful degradation, (6) Space-themed UI with glassmorphism and animations. Applicable to any domain requiring multiple API aggregation (weather, financial, news, etc.). **Pattern:** For multi-API platforms: (1) Create base client class with protected cachedGet/get methods, (2) Extend per service with specific TTLs based on data volatility, (3) Implement cache-first strategy with error fallback, (4) Use WebSocket for fast-changing data (5s updates), (5) Provide rate limit info in API responses, (6) Structure as monorepo: shared types + backend aggregator + frontend consumer, (7) Use TypeScript strict mode throughout for type safety, (8) Document all 50+ data sources in comprehensive guide.
